title: Friday, 16th September, 2016

annotations.prefLabel: Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC

bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Off we go then. TFIF.

BE

Where to start? Oh, a portrait. Of course.

BE

So: you've been hit by ....

11:02 am
BE

BE

You've been struck by ....

BE

11:04 am
BE

A foiled liminal.

BE

https://www.ft.com...-ae24-f193b105145e

BE

(Photo copyrights © Reuters and MJJ Productions, Inc / Youtube.)

11:04 am
BE

European officials have pushed back against British attempts to test secretly what terms are feasible in a Brexit deal, raising fears in London that its opening divorce demands will be set without any realistic guidance from the bloc.

BE

“They are testing, testing, testing,” said one senior EU diplomat. “And we are saying no.”
Another said: “We talk to the Brits all the time, but we will not talk about [free movement]. No way.”

BE

Cool.

11:05 am
BE

Head into the comments section on that article for lots of fun.

undefined
BE

While here, we have flat market -- as tends to be the case after quadruple witching.

11:07 am
BE

@Alchemy30 notes on the right that Ben's put a bit of meat on the old Mediclinic-Spire rumour.

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 371.70, up 10.8 (+2.99%), High: 371.90, Low: 363.60, Volume: 213.11k
BE

Not a new tale, as he says. See: https://www.ft.com...-a0b1-d87a9fea034f

11:08 am
BE

“Given demographic pressures and an overburdened NHS, we continue to believe the structural outlook for UK private healthcare remains compelling,” said JPMorgan. “We believe Mediclinic may wish to look at taking advantage of the recent weakness in sterling to buy out the rest of Spire.”

BE

He adds ...........

BE

But from what I understand from excellent sources is bankers from Morgan Stanley, Mediclinic's financial advisers, are actually working on the deal suggested by the JP Morgan analyst. One source reckons Mediclinic is just a few weeks away from submitting a formal approach for Spire. I don't have much more information than that but I have been told any offer is likely to be at about a 30pc premium to the current share price. - See more at: http://www.betavil...hash.jXw2nxC6.dpuf

11:09 am
BE

To which we have no further info, really.

BE

"A few weeks away from submitting a formal approach" will put it square into the Takeover Panel territory though.

BE

One could hope for a statement if what Ben's reporting is accurate, and one would hope that given recent speculation a statement will have already been drafted just in case.

11:11 am
BE

We'll see, though. I guess.

undefined
BE

(@ROTR: leave it.)

11:13 am
BE

So, Deutsche then.

BE

Confirms it's opened talks to settle RMBS misselling claims with the DOJ

BE

And that the DOJ wants $14bn. Deutsche, unsurprisingly, doesn't fancy paying that much.

11:14 am
BE

Now, there's always a bit of haggling in these negotiations. The difference is that Deutsche's quite far up the creek.

BE

And already trading at 0.4x current TBV, incidentally.

BE

RBC to put this in some context.

11:15 am
BE

We have assumed a settlement cost of $4bn in our forecasts for the RMBS working group including the DOJ, which assumes that 70% is already provisioned so a EUR1bn top up in provisions. The bank has a large stock of litigation reserves on its balance sheet of EUR5.5bn, of which EUR4bn is for regulatory enforcement as at H1
16. Every $1bn of higher provisions than in our forecast i s a 24bp hit to CET1. Given the fact that we expect the capital ratio to be 11% end 2016E vs. its target of greater than 12.5% by 2018 where the final se lement comes out is key.

BE

In terms of settlements from other banks the DOJ component of the RMBS working group settlements (FIRREA – civil penalty in the exhibit below) has varied from $2-5bn, although the total settlement amounts have been higher including settlements with other parties (federal states) and consumer relief, which is not a cash payment. Also we would expect other banks that have settled started with similarly high amounts from the DOJ at the beginning of the process – with the press reporting starting points of $12bn for Citigroup (Reuters, 16 Sept 2016) and $15bn for GS (FT, 16 Sept 2016) vs. final settlements of $7bn and $5.06bn, respectively. There is also the complication of the extent to which the figures include settlements with others in addition to the DOJ.

BE

European banks yet to settle on RMBS
None of the European banks has settled with the DOJ on RMBS yet so DBK is the first to enter negotiations with Barclays, UBS, CS and RBS also facing this issue. We have included provisions for the other banks in our forecasts ($750m for Barclays, $1.4bn for CS and $600m for UBS) although it is hard to know to what extent they may
already carry provisions for this matter. It is the biggest issue for RBS aside from DBK in our view. For RBS we include £2.5bn ($3.3bn) for litigation provisions in our forecasts for the RMBS working group.

11:15 am
BE

Our View
We would expect DBK’s final settlement to be significantly below the starting negotiation amount as seen at other banks although it remains uncertain where the final settlement will end up and the final impact on the capital ratios. Resolving this issue remains key for DBK as it will give more clarity on capital, although there are a number of other moving parts – namely the Russian equi es inves ga on and also the IPO of Postbank.

BE

And Goldman

BE

We note the following points:

(1) On September 9, Manager Magazin reported DBK was close to a settlement with the DoJ and that the amount could exceed US$2.4bn (2) It is unclear if the amount referenced includes consumer relief in addition to monetary payments. The highest RMBS-related monetary payment to the DoJ thus far was US$5bn (by BofA).

(3) DBK’s total on balance sheet litigation reserves stood at €5.5bn as of 2Q16; this includes provisions for all outstanding litigation, most notably RMBS and the Russian equities matter;
(4) Management stated with 2Q results that it aims to settle major outstanding litigation items (including RMBS and Russia) by year end.
(5) Deutsche Bank stated in its 2Q16 report that it has “received subpoenas and requests for information from certain regulators and government entities, including members of the Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities Working Group”. The DoJ is not the only member of the RMBS Working Group (see Ex. 1); DBK has already settled with the FHFA for US$1.9bn.

11:16 am
BE

Now, we'll get to a sensible analysis of this in a moment.

BE

First, though, can I try an insensible one?

BE

Investment idea: inverse weight banks in your portfolio based on how much they go on about their art collection.

11:16 am
BE

You'd have been deep underweight Deutsche, of course, which has 50,000 items dotted around its vaults, lobbies and meeting room walls.

BE

http://art.db.com/index_en.htm

BE

(To put that in context, the National Gallery has 2.3k.)

11:17 am
BE

You'd also be short Intesa .....

BE

http://www.group.i...rico_artistici.jsp

BE

And ABN Amro ...

11:17 am
BE

https://www.abnamr...lection/index.html

BE

And UBS

BE

https://www.ubs.co...t_collection/home/

11:17 am
BE

Oh, and Lehman.

BE

http://artdaily.co...llion#.V9vB5vkrLGg

BE

AIB, I seem to remember, had to flog its art collection in 2013 and got about £50 for it.

11:18 am
BE

Anyway, how does Deutsche get out of this?

BE

Merger with Commerzbank?

BE

Selling the asset management business?

11:18 am
BE

Or just pull the trigger on a rights issue to close a 2018 capital shortfall of €9bn-ish?

BE

Macquarie had a good note out overnight, pre the US litigation news.

BE

They go for option three.

11:19 am
BE

 The market is losing faith. Consensus for both profits and capital are now well below the target levels set last October. Estimates for 2018E ROTE are just 6.0% against a target of greater than 10% with net profit expectations having fallen 45% YTD. CET1 estimates leave no buffer for failure to divest Postbank or Basel IV. In this context, it is little surprise other options are being looked at.

BE

 Postbank is the key problem. We think much of the recent hand wringing on strategy is due to the difficulties of selling Postbank. If it cannot be divested, the capital shortfall will have to be filled some other way. We think this is the backdrop to the CBK talks and the debate over asset management. 2018E CET1 consensus is 12.5%, but assuming Postbank cannot be sold, this would drop to 11.2% vs greater than 12.5% target and a 12.25% SREP/G-SIB requirement.

BE

 CBK a highly unlikely solution. The only logic we can see to this deal is that it could optically improve DBK’s CET1 position through negative goodwill. However, on most other counts, it looks a non-starter to us, bringing huge execution challenges for only modest earnings accretion and increasing DBK’s balance sheet by ~40% and level 3 assets by ~20%.

11:20 am
BE

 Asset management. Divestments have been a recurring theme in recent years. Full disposal could help the CET1 position in view of €5bn of goodwill carried by the business. But the sticking points are profit dilution (DeAM contributes ~20% of group earnings) and the fact that the parts of AM that are most saleable are also those DBK would least like to part with i.e. DWS.

BE

 No quick fixes. Neither looks a likely solution to us. Instead we see: 1) a recommitment to selling Postbank with an extended timeframe, probably not before 2019; 2) amendment of the financial targets by pushing out the delivery horizon, especially ROTE; 3) increased cost reduction (a cost base of ~€20bn is more compatible with the ROTE goals than the current target of €22bn).

BE

(@Airborne: Metro Bank.)

11:21 am
BE

So anyway, sector response is predictable.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 186.10, down 8.1 (-4.17%), High: 189.00, Low: 184.70, Volume: 12.08m
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 165.15, down 4.35 (-2.57%), High: 167.85, Low: 164.60, Volume: 25.35m
11:21 am
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 566.60, down 5.4 (-0.94%), High: 570.60, Low: 566.00, Volume: 15.95m
BE

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily markets live thing.

undefined
11:23 am
BE

(@Damaging Director: one could argue that Vernon Hill is a work of performance art himself.)

BE

Okay, what else do we have? Spire up 7%, so definitely in statement territory .......

BE

To remind, Mediclinic has 29.9%.

11:26 am
BE

................ Just trying to work out whether it'd require a cash call, which'd be a tricky sell so soon after a profit warning.

BE

Oh, and to be fined under the "less exciting but perhaps interesting to someone" file .....

BE

.... been hearing that Shire has parted company with Deutsche Bank

11:28 am
BE

As advisor, I mean. Deutsche was in the group that did the Baxalta deal.

BE

Deutsche out, Citi in, I'm hearing. No idea if that has any impact on the M&A strategy. Probably not.

undefined
11:31 am
BE

Oh, and to retread yesterday's vague mutterings about RSA .....

BE

.... nothing significant to add apart from the fact that Morgan Stanley's pushing the stock.

BE

(@Vixal: just so you know, we take a zero-tolerance policy to backbiting via the comment box. Can you watch yourself a bit? Thanks.)

11:34 am
BE

Our analysis suggests ongoing restructuring efforts and an
improved balance sheet will support strong capital returns,
including a special dividend in 2018. We assume coverage with
an Overweight rating, price target 594p.

BE

Analyst is Nadine A van der Meulen, CFA

BE

Strong capital return upside. We expect the dividend yield to increase from 2.1%
FY15 to 7.0% by FY18 (4.6% FY18 base dividend), driven by underlying earnings
growth and an increase in the payout ratio from 38% of underlying earnings in
FY15 to 75% FY18. This includes a special dividend in 2018.
Further balance sheet strengthening. Our detailed analysis of RSA's capital
position and capital tiering suggests that, ahead of returning additional capital
beyond the base dividend, RSA is likely to strengthen the balance sheet by 1)
keeping the Solvency 2 ratio at the top of the target range (a task we believe
could be eased if it opts to follow Gjensidige in issuing S2 compliant Tier 1 debt);
2) improving the quality of the Solvency 2 ratio; and 3) reducing financial
leverage. We estimate it will take ~2-3 years to achieve a sufficiently comfortable
position to return additional capital beyond the base dividend.

11:35 am
BE

Wonder why Nadine uses her middle initial? Is there more than one Nadine van der Meulen, CFA, at MOST?

BE

Continued restructuring upside. We see over ~30% earnings growth FY16e-
FY19e, mostly driven by an increase in the insurance result, with improved
underwriting offsetting pressure from investment income. Our in-depth look at
RSA's regional businesses suggests the UK & Ireland and Scandinavia will
contribute most to the earnings uplift.

BE

Investment income continues to weigh on results. We expect investment income
to fall by ~35% in the next 5 years. In addition to lower reinvestment yields, we
model lower investment gains due to the expected 'pull to par' impact on the
bond portfolio value. Investment income and gains drop from nearly ~65% of
operating earnings in FY16e to ~35% by FY20e.
Attractive valuation. Our PT of 594p implies 17% upside. RSA trades at 11.6x
2017e P/E versus its main peers on 14.4x. We think a valuation more in line with
peers is justified, given similar earnings growth in later years and an uplift in total
capital return to a level broadly in line with the main peers.

11:35 am
BE

So there we go.

BE

Notable that RSA is now above the high reached on the back of the Zurich offer.

BE

.... though not, yet, above Zurich's actual 550p offer.

11:37 am
RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 531.50, up 1 (+0.19%), High: 534.00, Low: 526.00, Volume: 1.29m
undefined
BE

Spire now up 10.5%. Pressure on to say something.

11:39 am
BE

Bell Pottinger's the external flack for Mediclinic, I think.

BE

Without assuming anything whatsoever here, there's often a bit of tension in similar cases about whether to box themselves in with a statement or go pens down.

SVG Capital PLC (SVI:LSE): Last: 682.50, up 32 (+4.92%), High: 682.50, Low: 662.50, Volume: 696.15k
11:42 am
BE

Says it's had interest from elsewhere.

BE

As well as printing a 735p NAV, which makes the HarbourVest offer look a bit lowball.

BE

HarbourVest having offered 650p

11:44 am
BE

Here's Stifel.

BE

Stifel view: Our initial thought on the HarbourVest bid was that it was a bit premature using the 30/04/16 NAV, just before SVG was due to publish its NAV to 31/07/16, which includes the impact of the sterling devaluation. This has been borne out, with SVG bringing forward its results following the bid. The NAV at 31/07/16 was 735p, which was ahead of the Stifel estimate of 695p to 725p and compares with a last published NAV of 666p at 30/04/16. However, there is some note of caution on the NAV because on 12/09/16, Platform Speciality Products, the largest investment in the portfolio, was subject to a revision on loan note terms, which results in a £13m valuation decline, which is equivalent to 8pps. In order to avoid this detracting from what is a good set of results, we did query as to whether this could have been provisioned at 31/07/16; however, SVG’s advisers have said this was not possible.

BE

Whilst HarbourVest trumpeted the bid as being at a 2.4% discount to NAV, this discount rises to 11.6% taking into account the 31/07/16 NAV. This large differential will likely make many of the shareholders reappraise their thoughts on the situation.

SVG appears to have been looking for a ‘white-knight’ in recent days following the HarbourVest cash offer at 650p. The board says it has “received approaches from a number of credible parties, which the board believes may lead to an offer competing with HarbourVest and could deliver superior value.” Historically, bids have been difficult to execute in the listed private equity sector given the debate over portfolio valuations and change of control issues. Whilst we expect many other private equity houses to have a look at the situation, we would be surprised if any bidder made a cash offer significantly above the 650p from HarbourVest. However, if another bidder does emerge, HarbourVest may regret having ‘boxed itself in’ with a “final offer” on day one. 3i Group used a similar tactic in the 1999 bid for Electra and failed because the offer was too low and could not be increased. Another complication is that Coller has given an irrevocable undertaking to accept the offer on 20% of the shares to HarbourVest and HarbourVest has a further 8.5% following market purchases on Monday.

11:45 am
BE

I'm a wee bit surprised to see the shares trading so far through the offer .....

BE

..... since there's a reasonable chance here that HarbourVest chooses to pause for six months and becomes an irritant on SVG's shareholder list.

BE

I'd put that likelihood at least equal to a bump, or a higher offer from elsewhere.

11:46 am
undefined
BE

(@FitzLions: I'd hope the Panel were on the phone to Morgan Stanley -- its sole house broker -- immediately after last month's JP Morgan report to clarify things.)

BE

Elsewhere in sellside, RBC pushing Moneysupermarket.

11:50 am
BE

Our view: Moneysupermarket offers the only pure way to get exposure
to the structural growth opportunity in price-comparison websites. Based
on what we believe are realistic assumptions, the market provides 75%
revenue upside to 2021E. A differentiated product offering with exposure
to faster-growing verticals helps the company to stand out backed by
earnings growth CAGR of 16% 2016-2021E. Initiating with an Outperform
rating and 400p price target.

BE

Price comparison is still a structural growth opportunity. Despite success
by the major price-comparison websites (PCWs) in gaining market share
in motor insurance, we think the structural shift towards PCWs will
continue. Based on our analysis, total market revenue potential across
insurance, money products and energy is £5.5bn, a level far in excess of
the current marketplace of c£1bn; however this assumes every consumer
switches products on an annual basis. Using more realistic near-term
assumptions around how frequently consumers might switch providers
(such as customers switching home insurance every 2.5 years from the
current 4.0 years), we forecast PCWs to have 75% revenue upside to
2021E. This shift should benefit all players in the market, and we expect
Moneysupermarket (MSM) to deliver revenue CAGR of 10.4% 2016-2021E
along with double-digit earnings CAGR of 16% 2016-2021E.

BE

Eh!?

11:51 am
BE

Total market potential of £5.5bn!?

BE

Where's all that money coming from?

BE

Hidden commissions, right?

11:52 am
BE

Most financial services companies relying on hidden commissions have found life gets increasingly difficult, from a regulatory level ........

BE

............ But, hey, perhaps price comparison sites will be the exception. Who knows?

BE

Diversified product offering encourages consumer loyalty. Compared to
peers that are part of listed motor insurers, MSM has a more diversified
product offering that should encourage site traffic in a traditionally
competitive market. The company generates more of its revenue from
money products (24% vs 6% at Gocompare) and is the second-largest
player in the Energy market. As a result, the company has a strong
foothold in two of the market verticals that we expect to show fastest
growth. We think these two lines of business will form 46% of the group’s
revenues by 2018E (up from 36% in 2015A). A further differentiator
is MoneySavingExpert (MSE), the UK’s largest independent consumer-
advice website, giving MSM a route into a loyal customer base.

11:53 am
BE

Highly cash generative with an attractive yield. MSM’s business model
is highly cash generative and we forecast a FCF yield of 5.4% in 2017E.
The company offers an attractive 2016E yield of 3.3% vs internet-focused
peers (1.3% average). Despite this attraction, MSM continues to trade at
a discount to UK online aggregators on 22.0x 2016E earnings vs peers on
33.0x. We believe that YTD underperformance on concerns around the
competitive environment and Brexit provides a decent entry opportunity.

BE

Initiating with an Outperform rating and 400p price target. We value
Moneysupermarket using a DCF model forecasting to 2025E. Our price
target plus our 2016E dividend yield of 3.3% imply a 37% total return.

BE

£5.5bn of hidden fees. Hm. Okay.

11:55 am
undefined
Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 310.40, up 8.8 (+2.92%), High: 311.80, Low: 300.30, Volume: 686.69k
undefined
11:56 am
BE

It all feels rather Friday today. Sorry @Chad, nothing I've seen on Watchstone.

BE

Peel Hunt's house broker, by memory, but they don't seem to have pubbed on it this morning.

BE

Um ... and I guess we end where we started.

11:59 am
BE

*JOHNSON SAID TO SEE BREXIT TALKS LIKELY STARTING EARLY 2017

BE

Okay, what does that actually mean?

BE

Does that mean the April 2017 trigger remains the likely option?

12:00 pm
BE

Or does it mean talks about the triggering will only begin next year? It's all a bloody shambles.

BE

Anyway, we've limped to midday somehow.

BE

Oh -- for completeness, should note that SOBI CEO Geoffrey McDonough was on Bloomberg this morning.

12:02 pm
BE

On takeover stuff, he said: “We’re over and done with that chapter. It’s not something we’re actively pursuing":

BE

This all casts back to May, of course, and didn't really go anywhere: http://ftalphavill...rcling-sobi-again/

BE

Okay, let's close for the week.

12:04 pm
BE

Thanks for your comments. Most of them anyway.

BE

And we'll be back on Monday.

BE

Cheerio.

11:21 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 605.00, down 19.2 (-3.08%), High: 621.40, Low: 604.70, Volume: 3.02m
